thread.title: Udine gives some leftover campaign cash to his opponent
thread.title_full: Udine gives some leftover campaign cash to his opponent - Sun Sentinel

author: Brittany Wallman
title: Udine gives some leftover campaign cash to his opponent
text:
It doesn't happen often, but occasionally, a political race ends in the proverbial group hug.
The Democrat-versus-Republican race for Broward County Commission between Michael Udine and Pastor Randall Cutter is one of those races. The matchup came to an unusually friendly conclusion. Udine, the former mayor of Parkland, attended his opponent's church, and contributed $250 from his campaign stash to it.
 Udine won the race for District 3 in northwest Broward (filling the seat formerly held by Stacy Ritter). The victory was no surprise; like all nine districts in Broward, it leans Democrat in its voter registration.
Candidates with campaign cash left over can contribute it to a non-profit, return to contributors or put some in an office fund.
 Udine, who is Jewish, also gave to Jewish causes, including $500 to David Posnack Jewish Community Center and $500 to Soref Jewish Community Center. He transferred $8,263 to an office account.
Should Broward pay price in Tallahassee because Democrats won't pick Chip LaMarca to serve as mayor? Anthony Man The chairman of the Broward Republican Party has issued an unusual public complaint, suggesting County Commissioner Chip LaMarca is being illegally discriminated against by his Democratic colleagues — and suggesting top state leaders should consider punishing Broward.
"In this regard, as we begin...
The chairman of the Broward Republican Party has issued an unusual public complaint, suggesting County Commissioner Chip LaMarca is being illegally discriminated against by his Democratic colleagues — and suggesting top state leaders should consider punishing Broward.
"In this regard, as we begin...
(Anthony Man) Cutter said he and Udine had a "fairly good relationship'' with "many enjoyable interactions during the campaign.''
He said Udine met some of his volunteers, chatted with them, and decided before the election that he would visit Cutter's church afterwards, no matter the outcome, Cutter said.
"I agreed that would be an incredibly wonderful way to show how participants in a campaign should comport themselves after the election,'' Cutter said. 
 Udine stopped by Cutter's New Dawn Community Church on a post-election Sunday.
"He addressed the congregation, encouraging and complimenting them, and then presented us with a check to be used to bless the community in whatever way we saw fit,'' Cutter said. "t was a gracious thing to do, and reflected well on Michael as a person and a politician. My congregation warmly welcomed him, and we all applauded after his well-received comments.''
Broward's wish list: beach sand, affordable housing, and no fracking Brittany Wallman Broward County doesn't have the odds in its favor when it comes to seeking change, and dollars, out of the state Legislature. But county leaders sent up a long list of requests Tuesday, anyway.
On the list: funding for beach renourishment and affordable workforce housing, improved standards for...
Broward County doesn't have the odds in its favor when it comes to seeking change, and dollars, out of the state Legislature. But county leaders sent up a long list of requests Tuesday, anyway.
On the list: funding for beach renourishment and affordable workforce housing, improved standards for...
(Brittany Wallman) That's all well and good, but will that keep Cutter from running against Udine in 2020?
 "That is a funny question,'' Cutter responded by email. "I’ll side step it for now, since I haven’t given it any thought at this time.''
